WORLD BANK Staff Working Paper No. 328 May 1979 NUTRITION AND FOOD NEEDS IN DEVELOPING COUNTRIES This study presents an assessment of the problem of food supply and distribution in selected developing countries. Using fresh empirical evidence from household budget surveys, aggregate food supply and income distribution, two main conclusions are reached. First, the pattern of calorie consumption appears to be rather similar in the ,sample of countries considered, once variations of income and prices are taken into account. Second, if food prices increase and/or income distribution deteriorates in accordance with past trends, increases _n aggregate supplies of food would be insufficient to eliminate mal- nutrition in the next two decades. Therefore, food programs and market interventions will be necessary to reduce the severity of malnutrition and to reach certain segments of the malnourished population.  I. INTRODUCTION 1.01 Food security has been traditionally interpreted as the provision of adequate and secure fbod supplies at a country or regional level. This definition, however, fails to recognize that food security in developing countries presents two crucial dimensions. The first is the general problem of constrained food availability - of low growth In agricultural output, compounded by high variability in yields and quality of the produce, and foreign exchange limitations to the importation of food. The second a serious malnutrition problem of the poorest groups, who suffer from an inadequate intake of calories and other nutrients because they lack the income to buy a sufficient quantity of food. 1.02 While the general problem of constrained food availability has received the attention of many empirical studies, the nutritional probl- has been somewhat neglected because of the difficulty of drawing distribu- tional conclusions on the basis of the aggregate data available for develop- ing countries. Starting from a set of data from household consumption su 'ys, this paper therefore attempts to explore some of the aspects of this neglected dimension of food security by focussing on the distribution of calorie intake across income groups of selected developing countries: Bangladesh, India, Indonesia, Morocco, Pakistan and Sri Lanka. 1.03 Although the cases for study were chosen mainly on the ba;ls of the availability of reliable statistical information, the countries sceLcted have in common a number of important characteristics. First, by virtue of their size, income levels and food supplies, the six countries studied include the largest regional and aggregate concentrations of poverty ln the world. Second, all the countries have a per capita income below $200 in the base year and, with the exception of Morocco, are located in Asia. Third, the degree of income inequality is at the same time absolutely high as compared to average standards, but low in comparison to the inequality of many middle income countries in Africa and Latin America. In the countries included in this study, the poorest 252 of the population share from 10 to 18% of total income, while the richest 252 receive up to 482 of total income; this skewness of distribution is reflected to a considerable degree in the inequality of food consumption. 1.04 The methodology of the study is based on estimates of the relation- ship between calorie consumption and income levels using both intra-country aggregate data by income class and cr.os-country pooled data. The estimated relationships are then used jointly with supply function estimates obtained from other studies to project aggregate consumption and supply conditiors to 1985 and 1995 and to estimate the nutrition and total food gaps in thes. years before and after food price adjustments. Price responsiveness is both directly estimated and introduced in the demand function by estimating t'e income effect of a shift in the price of aggregate food under the assume tion that, at the low income levels of the countries in question, there is little scope for direct substitution between food and other commodities.

BACKGROUND, DEFINITIONS AND METHODOLOGY 2.01 To set the background for the analysis of food needs and malnutri- tion, it is useful to review the work of other studies that examine the 'ood situation in developing countries. Within the Bank, two major works have been completed. The first of these provides a background to the present study, in the form of estimates of the foodgrain situation of developing countries in 1985. I/ Using the trend growth in foodgrain production ' tween 1960 to 1975, the supply of foodgrains is projected to 1985. The differences between projected demand and supply are the estimates of the aggregate food deficits or surpluses in a set of developing countries. 2.02 The other major work provides both additional empirical background as well as some of the theoretical foundations for this study. 2/ It uses a low-response relationship between calorie consumption and income based on some evidence from cross-country estimates of average consumption valUes to project consumption and nutritional gaps for a large number of developing countries. One of the main empirical questions emerging from the study is whether the estimated low increase in calorie consumption associated with income irncreases is actually found in developing countries when consumption patterns of different groups rather than national average are compared. 3/ If the calorie responses to income increases are low, then 'normal' rates of income growth would have relatively minor impact toward eliminating malnutrition, and direct distribu- tion systems and food subsidies would be needed to supplement market distribu- tion. As a result of!this low responsiveness, the study proposes that: "Malnutrition is unlikely to disappear in the normal course of development: that is, in the course of normal per capita income growth, even with greater emphasis on expansion of food production barring, of course, unusual technological break-throughs."4/ 2.01 The International Food Policy Research Institute (IFPRI) has also conducted studies of food needs in developing countries.5/ In these studies, 1/ Sandra Hadler, Developint Country Foodgrain Projections for 1985, World Bank Staff Working Paper No. 247 (1976). 2/ S. Food needs are estimated by taking an average calorie require- ment, increasing it by 10% to account for the maldistribution of calories within countries, and multiplying it by the projected population for 1990. The issue raised by the IFPRI studies is whether the 10% factor applied uniformly across countries is a close enough estimate to account for the various differences in the distribution of income, nutrition preferences and habits, and hence differences in calorie consumption over income groups in developing countries. For the purpose of achieving a regional or worldwide estimate of food needs, such a factor increase may be sufficient to give "order of magnitude" estimates. It is certainly not sufficiently accurate to yield specific country estimates of food deficits or to determine the extent and severity of malnutrition in developing countries. Definitions 2.04 A number of concepts in the analysis require explanation. The calorie requirement is the minimum amount of calorie intake considered socially desirable for all individuals. For the purposes of this analysis it is assumed to be equal to a calorie requirement calculated using the FAQ/WHO methodology minus an allowance (of about 200 calories) to take into account individual variations of basic energy needs and variations of social stand- ards.1/ Food needs is the total amount of food that is necessary to meet both market demand and, if properly distributed between households and within families, to eliminate the calorie deficits of the poor. The availability of an amount of food equal to "food needs" would not necessarily alleviate malnutrition. Distributional systems would be needed to disburse food such that each income group formerly deficient in calorie intake receives just sufficient additional food to bring calorie consumption up to, but not exceeding, adequate calorie levels. However, the part of the population with high incomes would continue to consume above their calorie requirements, as dictated by their preferences and resulting food expenditure. Also, even if food were made available to a household in an amount that would meet or even exceed its average calorie requirements, maldistribution of food within the household could still result in malnutrition for some members, in partic- ular women and young children. Therefore, in an economic and political system that allows consumption above requirements according to preferences and income, "food needs" is the minimum requirement for food availability to provide adequate calories for the population; but even this may not be effective without the presence of other conditions. The availability of "food needs" is thus a necessary but not a sufficient condition for eliminating mal- nutrition. 1/ See FAO/WHO, Energy and Protein Requirements: Report on a Joint FAO/WHO Ad Hoc Expert Committee, Rome, FAO Nutrition Meeting Report Series No. 52 (1973). For a more detailed discussion of this topic see: P.V. Sukhatme, "A Statistical Appraisal of the Protein Problem" in Statistical Papers in Honor of George W. Snedecor, the Iowa State University Press, 1972, pp. 259-284.
 -5- 2.05 To measure the magnitude of the distributional aspects of malnutri- tion another measure is used, the nutritional Rap. The "nutritional gap" is the difference between the calorie intake of the malnourishec population and their recommended calorie intake plus an allowance (again of about 200 calories) to take into account waste, maldistribution within the family, and time variability of food supplies. Since calorie intake is a function cf income, the price of food and its availability, the nutritional gap is as much a measure of deficiencies in the distribution of income as it is of the distribution of food. The malnourished population or target popuilation f'r food policy is that portion of the population with a calorie availabll'.y below the requirement. Methodology 2.06 The methodology of this study can be summarized in the form of four sequential steps. First, calorie consumption by income groups is estimated using data from household consumption surveys: for each country in the study, the average quantities of the various food items consumed by ho,eholds in each income group are converted to calorie intake levels using FAO calorie conversion tables; the distribution of the population by class r-f calorie consumption is estimated by interpolating Lorentz curves, and ful,ctions relating calorie intake to total expenditure levels (used as proxies for disposable incomes) are estimated using weighed regression techniques. Because the functional form of the relations estimated allows demand el3sti- cities to change with income levels, this procedure gives income class and country specific estimates of the responsiveness of calorie consumption to expenditure changes. Second, calorie consumption by expenditure class is projected for various years under alternative policies affecting the real income levels of each group. Third, by comparing these intake levels with Lhe calorie requirement, the proportion of the population consuming below the norm (and the proportion consuming below other arbitrary levels) are estimated for the base period and the projection years 1985 and 1995 under alternative assumptions. Fourth, estimates by income class of the deficiencies in calorie intake from this requirement are also made and aggregated to yield the nutritional gap for the base year, 1985 and 1995. 2.07 The above procedure, which assumes at first unchanging relative prices was also repeated under the assumptions that food prices would adjust upward allowing the country to achieve a predetermined level of self-suffici- ency. In order to introduce the price effect in the model, two independent estimates were obtained by (a) adding a food price term to the calorie-income function to reflect the real income effect of price changes for food on per capita calorie intake for each income class 1/ and (b) fitting a calorie demand equation using the pooled sample of all countries. Also a supply function for food was computed by using a range of elasticity estimates from econometric studies of agricultural supply for each country in the sample. 1/ This term equals the income effect in the well known Slutsky de- composition of the price response in the demand function. It is likely to closely,reflect the full impact of price variation on demand for all consumers for which want-substitution between food and non-food is low.

A consistency check on the data was made by comparing the estimates of aggregate food consumption based on the household consumption surveys with the estimates of per capita calorie intake derived from aggregate food production and trade data. This consis- tency check indicated that the household consumption surveys for Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Indonesia and Morocco compared closely with aggregate figures. For India, household consumption surveys yielded higher consumption than aggregate food availability by about 15Z. No adjustments were felt warranted on the India data due to the large sample size of the survey and the consistency with the results of previous such surveys. As indicated by the lower production figures, any bias in the India data would be in a direction that would tend to underestimate the extent of malnutrition.

THE MAGNITUDES OF MALNUTRITION Econometric Results: Calorie Distribution and Income Responsiveness 3.01 Several factors are expected to influence the distributional aspects of malnutrition between household, including (i) income levels, (ii) household size, (iii) the consumption level already achieved, (iv) the price and availability of food, and (v) the specific dietary preferences of the different population groups. Using average figures of expenditure classes as observation points, however, the estimations show that at least 90% of the variation in the average level of calorie intake per capita between households wihin each country can be explained by average income levels. Also, across country estimates show that at' least 90% of the same variation in the pooled six country sample can be explained by differences in average income levels (converted at the official exchange rates) and in average food prices. 3.02 As shown in Table 1, the calorie response to increases in income at the calorie poverty line (i.e. at the expenditure level just sufficient to purchase the caloric requirement) varies from about 0.6 for Morocco and India to 0.5 for Indonesia, 0.4 for Bangladesh, 0.3 for Pakistan and 0.2 for Sri Lanka.l/ These magnitudes indicate that individuals consuming just at the caloric requirement will increase calorie consumption between 2% and 6% for every 10% rise in income. Moreover, the countries with the most significant magnitudes of malnutrition - Bangladesh, India and Indonesia - all have similarly high and not significantly different (from a statistical point of view) income elasticities and hence a high response in calorie consumption to income increases. The poorest 10% of the population of these Asian countries have calorie income elasticities of between 0.7 and 0.8 indicating that a 10% rise in income will increase calorie intake by 7 to 8% for the very poorest groups.  -8- 3.03 The magnitudes of the calorie responses estimated for each country suggest that real income gains of the very poor will have a more primary and direct effect on their nutritional status than had been previously concluded from cross-country evidence, even if they maintain their existing dietary habits and preferences. On the other hand, the fact that higher elasticities are associated with the large per capita deficits of the very poor means that consumption by a larger part of the population may fall below subsistence levels during poor crop years or, as in urban areas, during slumps in economic activity. The case for maintaining some type of reserve grain stock and distribution system is thereby supported. Furthermore, target group-oriented policy measures, such as ration shops and direct income subsidies, can play an important role in reducing malnutrition by offsetting price increases, directing supplies to those groups who are landless and unemployed, and supplementing the food purchasing power of the very poor. Even though a 10% growth in income for'the poorest groups would result in an increase in calorie consumption of about the same percentage, their consumption level is so significantly deficient (30% to 40% of requirements) that direct supple- mental food programs would be necessary to eliminate malnutrition. However, for the large bulk of the malnourished (those within 80% to 90% of calorie requirements) income growth will have a broad and significant impact in eliminating malnutrition. 3.04 In order to further illustrate the implications of the estimated response note that, although income growth may tend to eliminate the inter- household distributional aspects of malnutrition, the question remains as to whether malnutrition may be alleviated under current and projected growth rates in per capita income within an acceptable'time horizon. The answer depends on three factors: the rate of income growth, the extent to which the growth in income is shared among income groups, and whether the real price of food rises or declines. In Table 2, the relative range of growth rates in per capita income, postulated by the Bank and other sources, are shown. They range from relatively low growth rates in per capita income for Bangladesh (0.5 to 1.5%) to very high growth rates for Indonesia (2.0 to 5.0%). 3.05 Table 2 also shows the number of years (from base year) necessary to eliminate the deficits in calorie intakes for all but 5% of the population for each country. Under the low growth rate in per capita income, the prospects of income growth eliminating the distributional aspects of malnu- trition without supplementary food programs are dismal. However, if income growth at the higher expected levels is achieved, it appears that, except in Bangladesh and to lesser extent, in India, malnutrition between households for nearly all the population may be eliminated within about 30 years, that is, if income distribution does not deteriorate by more than 25% of the current Gini coefficient and food prices remain constant. If income redis- tribution results in a more equitable distribution and high growth rates in income are achieved, then malnutrition, at least in terms of having suffi- cient food available to the household, may be eliminated within 20 years. Thus, the estimated income calorie responses imply that income growth on the high end of the expected range could eliminate much of the distribu- tional aspect of malnutrition in the countries of this study.

THE PROSPECTS FOR ALLEVIATING MALNUTRITION 4.01 For the purposes of the projections attempted in this study, the possible food policy scenarios can be categorized into four general types of market interventions: (i) policies that through import or price constraints maintain constant food prices, (ii) policies that allow food prices to rise by some fixed amount, (iii) policies that allow food prices to rise to the point of self-sufficiency and, (iv) policies that allow a fixed amount or percentage of food imports and a consequential change in food prices. All these market interventions can be combined to some degree among themselves and with policies acting on variables other than prices such as, in particular, income and food distribution programs. Projections at Constant Prices 4.02 For all countries in the sample, projections at constant food prices are based on rather unlikely assumptions and should be interpreted only as ceteris paribus implications of the base year estimates. As Table 7 shows, for all countries except Bangladesh, the income increases implied by the high growth hypothesis would reduce the nutritional problem to manageable proportions by 1985 and nearly eliminate it by 1995. While a sizable number of people below the FAO/WHO standard persist under the low growth hypothesis, in all cases (but Bangladesh) the aggregate nutritional gap is such a small portion of market demand, that a marginal redistribution of food would be sufficient to wipe out the bulk of malnutrition within two decades. 4.03 Some of the trade-offs between income growth and redistribution of growth are further ilustrated in Table 8.  -20- V. MAIN FINDINGS AND CONCLUSIONS Patterns of Distribution and Responsiveness 5.01 The main findings of this study stem from the use of household survey aggregate data to measure (i) the pattern of calorie distribution, (ii) the extent of malnutrition, and (iii) the potential of the various income groups for improving their nutritional status via a general or specific increase in income. On these three accounts, despite the few data points available, the study provides fresh empirical information and evidence as to the conformity of the intra and inter-country consumption and response pat- terns to the hypotheses of economic theory. 5.02 One of the major findings of the study Is that income and food prices explain more than 90% of the variance of calorie intake both within each country and across countries. Moreover the poor are more responsive in their calorie consumption to income and price changes that had been previously postulated or estimated. As a consequence, relatively high income growth rates will significantly reduce inter-household malnutrition by 1995, provided that income distribution does not deteriorate or that large rises in the price of food do not occur. However, market simulations indicate that under histori- cal import level relative food prices will increase by 1.0 to 2.0% per annum for many developing countries, a fact that in addition to the prospects that income distribution may deterioriate is likely to cause widespread malnutrition by 1995. Food Production 5.03 A second major conclusion of this study is that historical growth rates in production, if they continue, will not be sufficient to provide the necessary food supplies to meet market demand and to meet the nutritional needs of the poor even if food prices are kept constant by government inter- vention. As a consequence, the necessary condition for eliminating malnutrition will not be fulfilled for many of the countries under historical growth rates in production. Food production must increase in the range of 3 to 4% per year in order to provide the necessary food supplies to meet market demand and provide for direct distribution to alleviate malnutrition. If food supplies either from production or imports are insufficient, prices of food will rise with major nutritional consequences for the majority of the population that do not gain in income from this price rise. income Redistribution 5.04 Our findings also indicate that while major income redistributions may have a dramatic impact on malnutrition, moderate levels of income redis- tribution will only reduce the calorie deficits of the poor and hence decrease the amount of time required for income growth to eliminate malnutrition. On the other hand, a worsening of income distribution in accordance to present trends will generally increase food needs and expand much beyond the next tw* decades the time required for moderate levels of income growth to end malnutrition.
 -21- Supplementary Food Programs 5.05 The study confirms that malnutrition is likely to be widespread and severe in the developing countries studied, and that malnutrition will continue to be a severe problem under projected income growth and food price increases. As a consequence, food programs and market intervention will be necessary to reduce the severity of malnutrition and to reach certain segments of the malnourished population. Although the need for a food intervention program will be significantly alleviated if high growth rates in income and food production are achieved, realistic scenarios suggest the continuing need for food programs at levels that will place severe burdens on government budgets and management.

The base year input data used in this case study was taken from the 1973/74 Houehold Budget Survey which presents the average quantity of food consumed per month by expenditure class. 1/ These food quantities were converted into calories using tables on nutrient values prepared by the Indian Council of Medical Research. Because the calorie intake levels for the two lowest expenditure clases were unreasonably low (495 and 871 calories), they were aggregated with the third class by taking a weighted average. (Table 4.1). Both classes combined accounted for approximately 1% of the population. The remaining data required for the regressions and the calcula- tion of income inequality (Gini coefficient) were also taken from the 1973/74 survey. Average daily calorie requirements for the base year 1973/74 (2,020), 1985 (2,033) and 1995 (2,041) were calculated using FAO/WHO standards'less 200 calories and assumed body weights of 50 Kg and 45 Kg for males and females respectively. (Table 4.2) ii. Extensive documentation on the survey design was not available at the time this study was completed. To check the plausibility of the derived calorie intakes the average intake implied by the expenditure data was compared to per capita availability of food in 1973/74 and to the findings of the 1975/76 Nutrition Survey. The derived calorie intakes compare closely with FAO per capita availability estimates (1,933 versus 1,971), and are only slightly lower than the results derived from the 1975/76 Nutrition Survey. The discrepancy can for the most part be explained by the higher per capita consump- tion of cereals estimated by the 1975/76 Survey (18 oz./day - 1,784 cal/day). Although it could be asserted that 1975/76 was a "good" year, this hypothesis is not supported by a comparison of estimates of foodgrain availablity between 1973/74 (15.9 oz./day - 1,576 cal/day) and 1975/76 (15.6 oz./day = 1,545 cal/day). Assuming that the Nutrition Survey data provide a more accurate measure of calorie malnutrition, the figure used in this study for the base year would, on average, tend to overstate the percent malnourished in 1985 and 1995 by 17 points. This would be equivalent to a reduction in the calorie requirement or an upward adjustment in intakes by 190 calorie/capita/day.  -49-. INDIA: Country Summary Data Base Data for India were derived from the 28th Round of the National Sample Survey (NSS). The Survey was conducted between October 1973 and June 1974 over the whole of India. Household expenditures for non-productive domestic consumption were collected for the period of 30 days preceding the Survey. The distribution of villages/blocks for the rural/urbai samples was determined on the basis of population so that the sample is self-weighted within the rural and urban sectors. The observations were on the household level defined as a group of people normally living and eating together. There were 15,467 rural and 7,881 urban households in the sample. The Indian government compiled the data into summary tables of average quantitites and expenditures for commodity groups by expenditure class. The amount of cereals consumed (derived from the summary tables) was directly converted to calories. In order to estimate total average calorie consumption, the cereal calories were increased by a proportion determined for each expenditure class - urban and rural. The proportion was derivfd from the 1971-72 NSS which has been converted entirely to calories by the FAO. it was based on the assumption that if (for example) cereal calories were 807 of totae calories in 1971-72, they would still be that percentage in 1973-74. Since the urban area was over-sampled on the basis of accual national population, the aggregation of rural and urban intakes by expenditure class was weighted by the true population percentages. The summary tables included an average total expenditure figure for each expenditure class. These were similarly aggregated to arrive at the national total expenditures utilized in the statistical analysis. The distribution of the population by classes of calorie consumption was obtained using the data of the 1971-72 NSS. Unlike the 1973-74 Survey, the 1971-72 NSS contains tabulations of calorie intake by consumption class. The same distribution was also estimated with the data from the 26th NSS using the distribution of households by expenditure class and their average per capita calorie consumption. No significant difference emerges from these two alternative calculations.

 -54- INDONESIA: Country Summary i Data on food expenditures (quantities) by income class as taken from the Fifth National Socio-Economic Survey, Susenas V, provided the base year input data for these projections. The data used in this study was disaggregated into 13 expenditure classes and included over 40 major foodstuffs from each of three sources: purchases, home production and gifts. Since the data was in terms of quantities, each food item was converted into its calorie equivalent so that a calorie expenditure elasticity relationship could be estimated. However, two adjustments of the data were made prior to estimation. ii For five food categories: vegetables, legumes, fruits, miscellaneous foodstuffs (incluOing sugar and oils) and the total prepared food category, expenditures rather than quantities were listed. Excluding these five cate- gories would have resulted in a national average per capita calorie intake significantly below that listed in FAO Food Balance Sheet (2031 versus 1767). To correct for this discrepancy a cost per calorie specific to each expenditure class was derived and used to convert the five food group expenditures into their respective calorie equivalents. The second adjustment made prior to *stimation of the calorie expenditure equation 'was the aggregation of the two lowest expenditure classes and of two middle expenditure classes leaving 10 classes altogether. This was done because calorie intake of the lowest class was unreasonably low (737) while that of the 8th class was unreasonably high (3922) relative to surrounding classes (2266 and 2657).

doc.abstracts: This study presents an assessment of the problem of food supply and distribution in selected developing countries. Using fresh empirical evidence from household budget surveys, aggregate food supply and income distribution, two main conclusions are reached. First, the pattern of calorie consumption appears to be rather similar in the sample of countries considered, once variations of income and prices are taken into account. Second, if food prices increase and/or income distribution deteriorates in accordance with past trends, increases in aggregate supplies of food would be insufficient to eliminate malnutrition in the next two decades. Therefore, food programs and market interventions will be necessary to reduce the severity of malnutrition and to reach certain segments of the malnourished population.
